head.title: Bush Must Stop Dithering on Global Warming

hedline.hl1: Bush Must Stop Dithering on Global Warming

block.p: Although Elliot L. Richardson correctly observes that little can be done to remedy global warming in the absence of multilateral institutions (Op-Ed, Feb. 7), he obscures a fundamental truth of politics when he implies that the heated arguments about ''the costs and benefits of international action'' avail nothing in the absence of implementing institutions.

As Mr. Richardson knows from his own bitter experience, broad consensus among nations and within governments about the severity of the problems to be addressed and the economic and political costs of international action must precede, not follow, the construction of legal and administrative institutions to execute international policy. The Reagan Administration's strong antipathy, on self-centered economic and political grounds, to the minerals regime of the Law of the Sea treaty scuttled 15 years of meticulous crafting of institutional structures in which Mr. Richardson played a prominent role. Thus, the debate within the Bush Administration and around the country about whether global warming is occurring, its effects and what responses we should take assumes central significance and urgency.

Until the Administration disavows ''tepid'' dalliance (editorial, Feb. 8) and affirms the wisdom of immediate preventive measures to mitigate future global climate change, we have no need of new multilateral institutions.
The writer is professor of environmental law, University of Houston.
